Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: Tonight is the only evening my girlfriend and I have together before I leave for a week-long work trip. She’s been looking forward to this, planning for us to go to the big community dinner everyone’s been talking about. I want to make her happy, to be present and share this time, especially since we’ve both been so busy. But as we walk into the hall, I scan the buffet and my heart sinks. None of the food is labeled kosher, and I can’t find anyone who knows for sure. There’s no way to bring in my own meal, and I know she’s excited to try everything with me. I feel her hand squeeze mine, her eyes bright with anticipation, and I feel the weight of my own expectations pressing in—her hope for a carefree evening together, my commitment to keeping kosher. I want to be the boyfriend she deserves, but I can’t ignore the part of me that’s Jewish, that’s always been careful about what I eat. The noise of the room fades as I stand there, caught between two worlds, not sure which part of myself I’m supposed to let down.
